The - I think it 's a two - stage idea. And, um,
the first stage of these features
correspond to what 's called the peripheral auditory system.
a filter bank with a compressive nonlinearity.
I 'm - I 'm not sure what we have
@ @ in there that isn't already modeled in something like,
um, PLP. I should learn more about that.
the most different thing, I think, from what we usually do. It 's, um -
sort of like based on diffe different w um, wavelet basis functions
So th he uses analysis functions called Gabor functions,
the idea is these are used to sample,
represented as a time - frequency representation.
So you 're sampling some piece of this time - frequency plane.
@ @ for - for one thing, you could use it,
um, in a - a multi - scale way. You could have these -
instead of having everything - like we use a twenty - five millisecond or so analysis window,
um, and that 's our time scale for features, but you could -
using this, um, basis function idea, you could have some basis functions
which have a lot longer time scale
and, um, some which have a lot shorter, and
so it would be like a set of multi - scale features.
Th - this is - because it 's, um - there are these different parameters for the shape of these
there are a lot of different possible basis functions. And so he -
an optimization procedure to choose an -
an optimal set of basis functions out of all the possible ones.
What does he do to choose those?
The method he uses is kind of funny - is,
he starts with - he has a set of M of them.
he - and then he uses that to classify -
I mean, he t he tries, um,
using just M minus one of them.
So there are M possible subsets of this
length - M vector. He tries classifying, using each of the M
the best, I guess, he says -
the - the fe feature that didn't use
so we 'll throw it out and we 're gonna randomly select
from the set of possible basis functions.
Yeah. So i so it 's actuall
it 's a little bit like a genetic algorithm or something in a way.
Well, it 's - it 's much simpler. But it 's - but it 's - uh, it 's - there 's a lot - number of things I like about it, let me just say.
So, first thing, well, you 're absolutely right. I mean,
both pieces of this are - have their analogies in stuff we already do.
at how to approach it and potentially one that 's
m maybe a bit more systematic than what we 've done,
uh, and a b a bit more inspiration from - from auditory things. So it 's - so I think it 's a neat thing to try.
Yeah, essentially, it 's - it 's, uh, you know, PLP or - or mel cepstrum, or something like that. You 've - you 've got some,
uh, compression. We always have some compression. We always have some - you know, the - the -
the kind of filter bank with a kind of
Um, if you put in - if you also include the RASTA in it - i RASTA - the filtering being done in the log domain
has an AGC - like, uh, characteristic, which, you know, people typi typically put in these kind of,
uh, auditory front - ends. So it 's very, very similar,
uh, but it 's not exactly the same.
I would agree that the second one is - is somewhat more different but,
um, it 's mainly different in that the things that we have been doing like that
had a different kind of motivation and have ended up with different kinds of constraints.
So, for instance, if you look at the LDA RASTA stuff,
you know, basically what they do is they - they look at the different eigenvectors out of the LDA and they form filters out of it. Right?
And those filters have different, uh, kinds of temporal extents and temporal characteristics.
And so in fact they 're multi - scale.
But, they 're not sort of systematically multi - scale, like " let 's start here and go to there, and go to there, and go to there ", and so forth. It 's more like,
you run it on this, you do discriminant analysis, and you find out what 's helpful.
I it 's multi - scale because you use several of these in parallel, is that right? Of -
Yeah. They use several of them. Yeah.
Uh, I mean, you don't have to but - but - but, uh, Hynek has.
Hyn - when Hynek 's had people do this kind of LDA analysis, they 've done it on frequency direction and they 've done it on the time direction.
I think he may have had people sometimes doing it on both simultaneously - some two - D - and that would be the closest to these Gabor function kind of things.
Uh, but I don't think they 've done that much of that.
And, uh, the other thing that 's interesting - the - the, uh -
the feature selection thing, it 's a simple method,
but I kinda like it. Um,
there 's a - a old, old method for feature selection. I mean,
eh, uh, I remember people referring to it as old when I was playing with it twenty years ago, so I know it 's pretty old,
uh, called Stepwise Linear Discriminant Analysis in which you - which - I think it 's used in social sciences a lot.
So, you - you - you - you pick the best feature.
you take - y you find the next feature that 's the best in combination with it.
And then so on and so on.
And what - what Michael 's describing seems to me much, much better,
because the problem with the stepwise discriminant analysis is that you don't know that - you know, if you 've picked the right
set of features. Just because something 's a good feature doesn't mean that you should be adding it. So,
uh, here at least you 're starting off with all of them, and you 're throwing out useless features. I think that 's - that seems, uh - that seems like a lot better idea.
Uh, you 're always looking at things in combination with other features.
so the only thing is, of course, there 's this - this
how you a how you assess it and if - if your order had been different in throwing them out.
I mean, it still isn't necessarily really optimal, but it seems like a pretty good heuristic.
So I th I think it 's - it 's - I think it 's kinda neat stuff. And - and - and, uh,
the thing that I wanted to - to add to it also was to have us use this in a multi - stream way.
when you come up with these different things,
you don't necessarily just put them all into one huge vector,
have some of them in one stream and some of them in another stream, and so forth.
And we 've also talked a little bit about, uh,
uh, Shihab Shamma 's stuff, in which
you - the way you look at it is that there 's these different mappings and some of them emphasize, uh, upward moving,
uh, energy and fre and frequency. And some are emphasizing downward and
fast things and slow things and -
So there 's a bunch of stuff to look at. But, uh, I think we 're sorta gonna start off with what
he, uh, came here with and branch out -
here, too, at the same time. So,
he 'll be another interesting source of wisdom.
As - as we were talking about this I was thinking,
um, whether there 's a relationship between -
between Michael 's approach to, uh, some - some sort of optimal brain damage or optimal brain surgeon on the neural nets.
we have our - we have our RASTA features and -
and presumably the neural nets are - are learning some sort of a nonlinear mapping,
uh, from the - the - the features
to - to this - this probability posterior space.
and each of the hidden units is learning some sort of - some sort of -
Right? And it could be, like -
like these, um - these auditory patterns that Michael is looking at.
And then when you 're looking at the -
the, uh, um, the best features,
you know, you can take out - you can do the - do this, uh, brain surgery by taking out, um, hidden units that don't really help at all. And this is k sorta like -
I mean, y actually, you make me think a - a very important point here is that, um,
if we a again try to look at how is this different from what we 're already doing,
a nasty argument that could be made th that it 's - it 's not different at - at all,
because, uh - if you ignore the - the selection part -
because we are going into a - a very powerful,
that, uh, in fact is combining over time and frequency,
and is coming up with its own - you know, better than Gabor functions - its, you know, neural net functions, its - whatever it finds to be best.
Um, so you could argue that in fact it - But I - I don't actually believe that argument because I know that, um,
added anything - in fact, you subtracted something, from the original waveform -
You know, uh, if you 've - you 've processed it in some way you 've typically lost something - some information. And so,
you 've lost information and yet it does better
with - with features than it does with the waveform. So,
uh, I - I know that i sometimes it 's useful to -
why it really seems like the constraint - in - in all this stuff it 's the constraints that are actually what matters.

Because if it wasn't the constraints that mattered, then we would 've completely solved this problem long ago, because long ago we already knew how to put waveforms into powerful statistical mechanisms.
Yeah. Well, if we had infinite processing power and data,
I guess, using the waveform could -
then it would work. Yeah, I agree.
Yeah. Then it would work. But - but, I mean, i it 's -
With finite of those things - I mean, uh, we - we have done experiments where we literally have put waveforms in and -
and - and, uh, we kept the number of parameters the same and so forth, and it used a lot of training data. And it - and it - it, uh -
not infinite but a lot, and then compared to the number parameters - and it - it, uh - it just doesn't do nearly as well.
So, anyway the point is that you want to suppress -
it 's not just having the maximum information, you want to suppress,
uh, the aspects of the input signal that are not helpful for -
for the discrimination you 're trying to make.
Well, that sort of segues into what - what I 'm doing.
so, uh, the big picture is k
um, come up with a set of,
uh, intermediate categories, then build intermediate category classifiers, then do recognition,
and, um, improve speech recognition in that way.
Um, so right now I 'm in - in the phase where I 'm looking at - at, um, deciding on a initial set of intermediate categories. And
I 'm looking for data data - driven
methods that can help me find,
um, a set of intermediate categories of speech that, uh, will help me to discriminate later down the line.
And one of the ideas, um, that was to take a - take a neural net -
train - train an ordinary neural net
uh, to learn the posterior probabilities of phones.
um, at the end of the day you have this neural net and it has hidden -
hidden units. And each of these hidden units is -
um, is learning some sort of pattern.
And so, um, what - what are these patterns? I don't know.
Um, and I 'm gonna to try to -
to - to see, um, from those patterns -
uh, presumably those are important patterns for discriminating between phone classes. And maybe -
maybe some, uh, intermediate categories can come from
just looking at the patterns of -
um, that the neural net learns.
Be - before you get on the next part l let me just point out that s there 's - there 's a - a pretty nice
relationship between what you 're talking about doing and what you 're talking about doing there. Right? So,
it seems to me that, you know, if you take away the - the - the difference of this
and, say, you use - as we had talked about maybe doing - you use P - RASTA - PLP or something for the - the primary features,
is just what he 's talking about doing, too,
except that he 's talking about doing them in order to discover intermediate categories that correspond
to these - uh, uh, what these
sub - features are - are - are - are showing you.
he 's doing this in a - in a multi - band setting,
which means that he 's constraining himself
to look across time in some f relatively limited, uh, uh, spectral extent. Right?
And whereas in - in this case you 're saying " let 's just do it unconstrained ".
So they 're - they 're really pretty related and maybe they 'll be - at some point where we 'll
see the - the connections a little better and
Yeah, so - so that 's the - that 's the first part - uh, one - one of the ideas to get at some -
uh, come up with a - a - a model - um, a graphical model,
as hidden - hidden variables, latent variables, that we don't know anything about,
um, s statistical training and the EM algorithm, um, at the end of the day, we have, um -
we have learned something about these - these latent, um - latent variables which happen to correspond to intermediate categories.
Yeah, and so those are the - the two directions that I 'm - I 'm looking into right now. And, uh,
Yeah. I guess that 's - that 's it.
Should we do our digits and
Yeah. It 's kind of like, you know, the little rats with the little thing dropping down to them. We do the digits and then we get our treats.
OK. Transcript L dash three seven one.
